verses.text: Paul, a prisoner of Christ Jesus, and Timothy our brother,
To Philemon our dear friend and fellow worker, to Apphia our sister, to Archippus our fellow soldier and to the church that meets in your home:
Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
I always thank my God as I remember you in my prayers,
because I hear about your faith in the Lord Jesus and your love for all the saints.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:1
rsbNotes.text:
1 prisoner. Paul knows that he belongs to Christ, and if he is in prison it is by Christ’s permission (Phil. 1:7).

in your house. The early Christians met in believers’ homes (1 Cor. 16:19; Col. 4:15).

verses.text: I pray that you may be active in sharing your faith, so that you will have a full understanding of every good thing we have in Christ.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:6
rsbNotes.text: 6 may become effective. Paul is going to suggest a good work that will call on Philemon’s generosity in an important and visible way.

verses.text: Your love has given me great joy and encouragement, because you, brother, have refreshed the hearts of the saints.
Therefore, although in Christ I could be bold and order you to do what you ought to do,

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:7
rsbNotes.text: 7 hearts. The word translated “hearts” is used also in vv. 12 and 20. It emphasizes the emotions more than the usual Greek word for “heart.”

verses.text: yet I appeal to you on the basis of love. I then, as Paul--an old man and now also a prisoner of Christ Jesus--

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:9
rsbNotes.text: 9 an old man. Paul appeals for mercy by describing himself as old and in prison. He does this “for love’s sake,” not for his own sake.

verses.text: I appeal to you for my son Onesimus, who became my son while I was in chains.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:10
rsbNotes.text: 10 my child, Onesimus. Onesimus is Paul’s spiritual son because he was converted through Paul’s ministry.

verses.text: Formerly he was useless to you, but now he has become useful both to you and to me.
I am sending him--who is my very heart--back to you.
I would have liked to keep him with me so that he could take your place in helping me while I am in chains for the gospel.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:11
rsbNotes.text: 11 useless . . . useful. Paul makes a play on words—Onesimus’s name means “useful” or “beneficial” (text note). The pun softens the effect on Philemon of having to hear about someone who had injured him. Onesimus had run away and had probably been stealing (v. 18).

verses.text: But I did not want to do anything without your consent, so that any favor you do will be spontaneous and not forced.
Perhaps the reason he was separated from you for a little while was that you might have him back for good--

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:14
rsbNotes.text: 14 of your own free will. In his letters Paul appeals more than once to the principle that a free and voluntary action is of more value than one that is compulsory (1 Cor. 9:16, 17; 2 Cor. 9:7).

verses.text: no longer as a slave, but better than a slave, as a dear brother. He is very dear to me but even dearer to you, both as a man and as a brother in the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:16
rsbNotes.text: 16 more than a slave. Paul seems to be asking Philemon to set Onesimus free. It is implied that the Christians’ common freedom in Christ is incompatible with the state of slavery, marked as it is by compulsion (v. 14 note), not to mention chains (v. 10, 13, 14; see 1 Pet. 2:18 note).

verses.text: So if you consider me a partner, welcome him as you would welcome me.
If he has done you any wrong or owes you anything, charge it to me.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:17
rsbNotes.text: 17 as you would receive me. Paul is willing to throw his friendship with Philemon into the balance to make sure that Philemon will not refuse his request for Onesimus. Paul’s offer to pay Onesimus’s debts (v. 18) is real, but secondary by comparison.

verses.text: I, Paul, am writing this with my own hand. I will pay it back--not to mention that you owe me your very self.
I do wish, brother, that I may have some benefit from you in the Lord; refresh my heart in Christ.
Confident of your obedience, I write to you, knowing that you will do even more than I ask.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:19
rsbNotes.text: 19 even your own self. This means that Philemon, like Onesimus, owed his Christian faith to the ministry of Paul.

verses.text: And one thing more: Prepare a guest room for me, because I hope to be restored to you in answer to your prayers.
Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus, sends you greetings.
And so do Mark, Aristarchus, Demas and Luke, my fellow workers.
The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.

rsbNotes.title: Philemon 1:22
rsbNotes.text: 22 a guest room. Paul anticipates being released, which apparently happened. Whether he reached Colosse is not known.
